items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  8.02
			 
			 
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Dale Scott, Financial Advisor, Dale Scott & Company, and Charles Adams, Jones Hall 
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2013/2014-05 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of General Obligation Bonds, 2012 Election, Series A, in the Principal Amount of Not to Exceed $20,000,000
			 
			 
			 
At an election held on November 6, 2012, the voters of the District approved a ballot measure (Measure I) authorizing the issuance of general obligation bonds in the principal amount of $120 million.  The vote was held pursuant to Proposition 39, which required at least a 55% approval rate for passage, with the actual passage rate being 71.5%.
			 
In anticipation of the issuance of the first series of bonds under Measure I, the Board previously adopted a resolution on June 11, 2013, requesting the County of Santa Clara to levy a property tax for payment of an initial series of the bonds during fiscal year 2013-2014, in the principal amount of approximately $40 million.  At its meeting on August 22, 2013, the Board adopted a resolution authorizing the issuance of the first series of bonds under Measure I in the principal amount of not to exceed $20 million, and authorized a judicial validation action to be filed with respect to the expenditure of a portion of the bond proceeds on the proposed Educare Project.
			 
The purpose of the new proposed Board Resolution is to formally set forth all of the detailed terms and conditions for the issuance and sale of the first series of bonds under Measure I, including provisions relating to interest rates, maturities and redemption provisions, as well as provisions establishing a Debt Service Fund and a Building Fund with the County Treasurer.  As provided in the Board Resolution, the bonds will be issued entirely in the form of current interest bonds (with interest being paid on a semiannual basis on February 1 and August 1 of each year), and does not permit the bonds to be sold in the form of Capital Appreciation Bonds.  The Board Resolution authorizes the sale of the bonds on either a competitive or negotiated basis as determine by the Superintendent, and approves documentation relating to the sale of the bonds.  The Board Resolution approves a Preliminary Official Statement which will be used in connection with the sale of the Bonds, and authorizes District staff to take all actions needed to close the bond issue, including signing all required closing documents.
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$20,000,000.00
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2013/2014-05 authorizing the Issuance and Sale of General Obligation Bonds, 2012 Election, Series A, in the Principal Amount of Not to Exceed $20,000,000.00.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2013/2014-05 authorizing the Issuance and Sale of General Obligation Bonds, 2012 Election, Series A, in the Principal Amount of Not to Exceed $20,000,000.00.

Item:  8.06
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Measure E Distribution for Latino College Preparatory Academy and Charter School
		 
On February 19, 2009, the Board of Trustees approved a Measure E Prioritization List that allocated funds to LCPA (Board item 13.03).  On August 19, 2010, the Board approved a Measure E base allocation of $740 per one time maximum ADA for high school age District resident students attending charter schools within the District for technology and equipment procurement; the approved total maximum distribution to LCPA is $301,920.00 (Board item 14.02).  In addition, the Board approved LCPA’s Technology Plan, and authorized distribution of $111,710.00 to proceed with the purchasing and implementation of that plan.  
		 
To date, $275 million of the Measure E $349 million bond authorization has been issued (78.68%).  When LCPA approached staff on this matter, it was discovered that purchases have been made on LCPA’s behalf in excess of previous Board approval, but within LCPA’s maximum distribution; this excess expenditure requires Board ratification and Administration now requests ratification.  
		 
Board Approved Measure E Base Allocation for LCPA
$301,920.00
Maximum current distribution, based on 78.68% Measure E bonds issued
$237,550.66
Previously authorized distribution
$111,710.00
Value of equipment purchased in excess of authorization
$  96,827.99
FISCAL IMPACT:
$96,827.99
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E bond funds
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify expenditures of $96,827.99 of Measure E bond funds for provision of equipment for Latino College Preparatory Academy and Charter School.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.07
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager, and Kenneth Kerch, AIA, SGI Bond Program Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Facilities Planning and Associated Architectural Service Contracts at Independence High School
	 
	 
Independence High School (IHS) was originally master planned in 1969, and opened its doors to students in 1976.   In 2004, Perkins & Will developed an updated Facilities Master Plan for IHS.  With the passage of time since the 2004 Facilities Master Plan, the modernization plans made in 2008-09 for the Measure E bond program, voter approval of Measure I in November 2012, and the fire that burned the B Commons building in March of this year, facilities planning efforts have focused on aligning current and future facilities improvements with academic strategies and available funding.
	 
These facilities planning guiding principles were employed to provide a framework by which options were considered:
Flip the “front” of the campus to North Jackson Avenue on the east side of the site, which nearly everyone already treats as the front of the campus.  The North Jackson Avenue east side of the campus has a more direct vehicular approach from the neighboring community, expansive areas of existing parking, and three existing pedestrian/vehicular entries. 
Create a stronger entrance experience on North Jackson Avenue.
Complete the entire modernization scope of Performing Arts Center Building F (Phases 1 and 2).
Take advantage of the March 3, 2013 fire at B Commons by designing this building to house a school program that will reinforce the reorientation of the campus toward North Jackson Avenue.
Reduce the expansive size of Independence High School by creating an external entity “buffer zone” on the west side of the campus (Educational Park Drive).  Many of the existing facilities on the west side of the campus are currently occupied by non-IHS entities (San Jose Public Library, Adult Education, Pegasus, KIPP, San Jose State University, County Office of Education), which have a stronger physical presence on the west side than Independence High School itself.  The creation of this buffer zone would result in a reduced physical footprint, creating a campus size in alignment with current and projected future enrollment.  This reduced size would facilitate a more intimate feeling school, improved security for IHS, and reinforce North Jackson Avenue as the “front” of the campus.
Improve campus navigability through intuitive way finding measures, supplemented as needed by way finding signage.
Make plans in alignment with currently available funding, but with consideration for additional future work as funding becomes available.
	 
Representatives from Facilities Planning, SGI Program Management, IHS administration and School Site Council, and Superintendent’s Council, along with architects and construction managers currently working on active projects, have met on numerous occasions in the past months to identify options, and consider them in the context of the guiding principles listed above.  The process began with a review of the project priority list developed in 2008 (Attachment A), supplemented with newly identified projects and reflective of projects that have already been completed; priorities were reconsidered, and a current project priority list includes work that can be implemented immediately as well as projects on a longer (and currently unfunded) planning horizon (Attachment B).
	 
IHS has a unique and timely opportunity to affect Measure E (Phase 2) projects that are currently in preconstruction or construction phases, and commence the next round of projects (funded by Measure E, Measure G site improvement, Measure I, and insurance claim monies) to immediately implement this updated facilities plan, as follows:
	 
Convert Building N to house Administration, School Health Clinic, Academic Tutoring Student Center / Cybercafé, Counseling Center, Parent Center:
	 
Relocation of Administration to Building N was a low priority on the 2008 IHS project priority list, but it has risen in priority now because of a timely opportunity.  Building N (together with Building G) have been designed to be modernized, and a construction contract was awarded in late June 2013.  In order to modernize Building N, the existing occupants were relocated to other facilities:  Physical Conditioning was relocated to Building M; World Languages was relocated to Building E; the Book Room was relocated to the Library Building B.  Those relocated programs are perfectly happy in those facilities, and the programs are housed adjacent to complimentary programs; the “temporary” housing is well-placed, and with some very minor upgrades those programs can remain permanently in those spaces.
	 
This creates an opportunity to relocate the programs currently housed in Building H (on the west side of the campus, within the “buffer zone”) to Building N, and co-locate new academic support programs that are aligned with current educational delivery objectives.  Administration’s relocation to Building N would reinforce N. Jackson Avenue as the front of the campus, and remove this IHS program from the “buffer zone”.  
	 
To do so would require making minor design revisions focused primarily on furniture solutions.  However, given the change of use, the Architect of Record Cody Anderson Wasney Architects (CAW) is required to make revisions to the drawings and submit these revisions to Division of the State Architect (DSA).  With the exception of providing toilet facilities for the staff, these modifications are minor in nature and will require minimal review by DSA. It is anticipated that DSA review will occur in a timely fashion that will have only a minor impact on the current construction schedule of the project.  As this does represent architectural work effort exceeding that which is currently under contract, it requires a change order to CAW’s current architectural services agreement for the modernization of Building N.
	 
B Commons/Building G
	 
The March 2013 fire in B Commons provides an opportunity to rethink where the Art Department is located.  The Art Department can easily fit into the B Commons, and even allows for a gallery space to be added.  Relocating Art to the B Commons would further reinforce the migration of programs toward the Jackson side of the campus, and remove yet another IHS program from the “buffer zone”.  
	 
CAW’s current architectural services agreement for the modernization of Building G will be affected by this change, in that their construction administration services and associated fee can be removed from the contract via a deductive change order.  As CAW is intimately familiar with the Art Department’s program, they are uniquely suited to redesign the B Commons for Art; this would require a new architectural services agreement for the redesign of B Commons.
	 
Building F Performing Arts Center
	 
As a result of funding constraints, the Performing Arts Center Building F is currently being designed to be constructed in two (2) phases:  the entire scope of work is being designed concurrently, but the work is indicated on the drawings as “Phase 1” or “Phase 2”.  If constructed in a single phase, a construction cost savings of $200,000 would be realized and one year would be shaved off the construction schedule.  As an added bonus, Building G (or part thereof) can be used as temporary housing and/or storage for Building F programs while Building F is under construction. No changes are required to the CAW architectural services agreement for modernization of the Building F.
	 
Streetscape Improvements for a strong entrance experience on North Jackson Avenue
	 
To create a strong and intuitive entrance experience and further reinforce North Jackson Avenue as the front of the campus, a streetscape improvement project would include the installation of attractive, low maintenance and drought tolerant landscaping and the construction of hardscape that clearly reinforces a “place of arrival” to the campus, including new fencing, a new marquee, way finding signage, improved drop off/pick up zones, and parking lot asphalt repairs.  The scope and design intent of this work will be considered the initial implementation phase, with a goal of expanding this improved aesthetic and vernacular into the campus as funding becomes available in the future.
	 
Infrastructure
	 
Infrastructure condition studies are in process.  There is a high probability that a portion of the Board’s $32.5M of discretionary Measure I funding that was preliminarily earmarked for infrastructure upgrades will be allocated to IHS.  
	 
Funding available to support these project components is:
	 
Measure E
$16.0M
Measure G site improvements
$  0.5M
Measure I – IHS allocation
$  2.8M
Insurance claim proceeds (Fund 67)
$  1.5 – 3.0M
Measure I - Infrastructure
$  3.5 – 5.0M
Total
$24.3 – 25.8M
	 
Planning includes not only what facilities improvements will occur, but also how they will be packaged and delivered.  By engaging a single architectural firm for IHS, that firm has the ability to have a broader and longer range perspective in campus facilities planning, coordination, sequencing, and design.  CAW has been a very good business partner on the projects in which they’ve been engaged (Buildings F, G and N), and their continued and enhanced participation will allow them to work at an even higher level of inspired problem solving.  This “one architect, one construction manager, one contractor” approach facilitates efficiency, effectiveness and coordination, and there is an associated reduction in soft costs. Similar to the architectural firm, we are planning to present a contract scope and fee augmentation for the construction manager to the Board in October.  We are also exploring a Lease/Lease Back (LLB) construction delivery approach to identify a single contractor to execute the work, and will present information to the Board in the coming months that will provide an opportunity for education and discussion about the LLB delivery method.
	 
In summary, there is an immediate desire to take advantage of timely opportunities delineated in this report for capital construction work at IHS.  The critical timing is related to projects currently in design or construction, the fire in B Commons, and a strategic bundling of projects under one architectural firm’s oversight.  Independence High School’s Site Council and Administration, with concurrence from Superintendent’s Council and the Facilities Planning team support the following CAW contract changes, in order to execute implementation of the campus facilities plan:
Modify Cody Anderson Wasney Architects current architectural services contract for Buildings N and G, to make revisions to Building N for the program changes delineated above, to remove unnecessary construction administration scope related to Building G, and to add full architectural services related to streetscape and infrastructure improvements.
	 
Original Contract Amount 
$266,000.00
Change Order #1 (Board approved 5/9/13)
-$4,501.00
Contract Amount Prior to This Change Order
$261,499.00
Change Order #2
$507,320.00
Revised Contract Amount
$768,819.00
	 
Award a new architectural services contract to Cody Anderson Wasney Architects for modernizing B Commons for Art. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$881,443
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E – IHS allocation $457,320
Measure G $50,000
Fund 67 $374,123
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Amendment No. 02 to Work Authorization No. 01 and Change Order No. 02 to Purchase Order #201162 to redesign building N and reduce scope on building G for the Independence High School Modernization of Buildings N and G (Project Nos. E-065-004/005) with Cody Anderson Wasney Architects for an increased amount not to exceed $507,320.  Change Order No. 01 to Purchase Order #201162 is attached for reference (Attachment C).
		 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve a new architectural services contract for the Independence High School Modernization of B Commons Building (Project No. Z-065-601) with Cody Anderson Wasney Architects in an amount not to exceed $374,123.

SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 7:00 p.m. for Resolution #2013/2014-06 Regarding the Gann Spending Limit
			 
			 
In accordance with the California Education Code, a public hearing is to be held prior to the adoption of Resolution #2013/2014-06 Gann Spending Limit. 
			 
The Gann amendment limits the growth rate of income for state and local governments including school districts.  Each year, school districts and other agencies affected by the Amendment must calculate their Appropriations Limit for the coming year.  There is not direct relationship between the figures, which appear in the calculations of the Gann Limitation and other 2013/2014 budget data since the calculation deals exclusively with the proceeds of taxes.
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
Not Applicable

Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at  Approximately 7:10 p.m. for Resolution #2013/2014-04 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials per Education Code 60119
	 
BACKGROUND
Education Code Section 60119 requires that local Board of Education hold a public hearing and declare by resolution whether or not all students have access to sufficient instructional materials consistent with the State curricular frameworks and standards.  If the Governing Board finds an insufficiency, it must make known to the public the reasons for the insufficiency and take action to ensure that the situation is remedied within eight weeks from the start of school.  This public hearing is intended to comply with the regulation.
	 
Please be advised that the present California State per pupil allocation for the purchase of instructional materials is sufficient to provide each student with instructional support materials for each class for school year 2013-2014.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees determine a finding of sufficiency in instructional materials and supplies as specified in Resolution #2013/2014-04 and hold a public hearing with due diligence on September 19, 2013, as required by the Education Code Section 60119.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.04
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
					 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2013/2014-04 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials
	 
BACKGROUND
In 2000, a class action lawsuit was filed claiming that some public schools were failing to provide students with equal access to instructional materials, safe and decent school facilities, and qualified teachers.  In 2004, the case was settled and required school districts to ensure that all students had access to the approved instructional supplies (textbooks).  Governing Boards are required to hold a public hearing certifying that it has sufficient instructional materials for each student in its district.  For schools that are in the lower deciles based on the API ranking are visited by the County Office of Education to verify that each student has been issued a textbook and to evaluate the condition of the facility.  For ESUHSD, the schools that are visited are Andrew Hill, W.C. Overfelt, Yerba Buena, and James Lick.  The Santa Clara County has certified that each of the four schools have met the “Sufficiency of Textbooks” requirement.  The certification for the schools that are not visited is done by the principal.  Each principal, from the non-visited schools submit a signed “Certification of Textbook Sufficiency”.  
	 
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2013/2014-04 as proposed.

SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion Regarding Vietnamese Language Program
	 
	 
Per the Board's request this is an update on our Vietnamese Heritage Speakers program.  The district has been at the forefront of providing a Vietnamese Heritage Speaking program and has written the textbook for the courses.  In addition, the district has had a long history of certifying students as being bilingual/biliterate well before the county and the state developed their certification.  However, the district recognizes that there is a need to update the program due to changes in the UC World Language requirements and the needs of our student population.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion regarding Assembly Bill 9 (or Seth's Law) Anti-Bullying Service Delivery Model
	 
	 
The issue of bullying has plagued many school systems across the nation. We have all read about issues of bullying causing students to take drastic measures to escape the pain. Unfortunately, many of these drastic measures have resulted in suicide and/or murder.  Bullying is also linked to many negative outcomes including impacts on mental health and substance use.
	 
East Side Union High School District is committed to each student’s success in learning within a caring, responsive, and safe environment that is free of discrimination, intimidation, harassment and bullying.  On June 21, 2012, Board Policy 5131 Students – Conduct was amended and Board Policy 5131.2 Students – Bullying was adopted to comply with updated legislation, Assembly Bill 9. Board Policy 5131.2 Students – Bullying includes information on prevention, intervention and the process for handling complaints of bullying and cyberbullying. These policies prohibit discrimination, intimidation, harassment and bullying based on the actual or perceived characteristics set forth in Sections 422.55 and 220 of the Penal Code, and disability, gender, gender identity, gender expression, nationality, race or ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, or association with a person or group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics.
	 
The District has adopted a process for receiving and investigating complaints of this nature as well as including bullying prevention strategies in the comprehensive safety plans.  In addition, staff and administration have received professional development training related to student discipline and bullying.
	 
District Initiatives:
All school administrators were provided with training materials on how to identify when bullying is taking place and ways to intervene.  The administrators then used these materials to provide training to all staff.
Some schools have conducted school-wide lessons with students so that they understand how devastating bullying is and how they can prevent or intervene when bullying occurs.
An anonymous hotline for each school is available for students and/or parents to report bullying incidents.
Administrators and support staff received training from legal counsel, Dora J. Dome, regarding the latest procedures in due process and the new requirements under Assembly Bill 9..
Education Code and Board Policies continue to be updated to comply with legislation.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
For information only.

Item:  12.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding Introduction to the Common Core Standards
	 
	 
The US Department of Education has spearheaded the effort for states to adopt the Common Core State Standards (CCSS) in Mathematics, ELA, and Literacy in History/Social Science, Science, and the Technical Subjects. Forty-two states across the country have adopted the Common Core State Standards which cover grades K - 12 and are designed to prepare students for success in college and careers. The Common Core State Standards increase the rigor of what students are expected to do at each grade level and changed the content standards in grades K-11 mathematics. The first Common Core State Standards assessments will be given in grades 3 - 8, & 11 in the spring of 2015 in Math, ELA, and Literacy. This presentation is meant to be a brief overview which will be followed with a more in depth study at the October Special Board Meeting.

Pursuant to State mandate, the Governing Board must approve provisional internship permit requests allowing the district to employ and assign teacher(s) or administrator(s) who do not hold appropriate credential authorization.

TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Accept Unaudited Actual for Fiscal Year 2012/2013
			 
Attached for your review is a copy of the 2012-13 Unaudited Actual Financial Report.  The report provides a detailed summary of the District’s fiscal status as of June 30, 2013.  Your approval is required to certify the 2012-13 unaudited actual financial reports as required by Education Code 42100. In addition, your approval will establish appropriations to account for differences between the estimated year-end balances and the unaudited year-end balances as required by Education code 42600 prior to submission to the County Office of Education and to the State.  The formal due date to the County Office is September 15, 2013.   
			 
INCLUDED IN YOUR PACKET:
A SACS binder detailing General Fund revenue and expenses for FY 2012-13 estimated actual vs. 2012-13 unaudited actual.  Also included are detailed summary information highlighting the same type of information for each fund including special revenue funds, capital project funds, and proprietary funds.  All summary worksheets prepared reflect the information required by the state for Unaudited Actual which are shown on the SACS forms.  
A Powerpoint presentation highlighting the 2012-13 Unaudited Actual Financial Report.
			 
ESTIMATED ACTUALS vs. UNAUDITED ACTUALS
Each year districts are required to include an estimate of the ending fund balance for each fund with the Budget Adoption process.  It was estimated when the budget was adopted that the general fund ending fund balance would be $38,486,700.00 and the Unaudited Actual for the General Fund totals $40,410,748.00.  The variance between the estimated actual vs. unaudited actual represents an increase of $1,924,048.00 to the 2012-13 Ending Fund Balance which has been brought forward into the 2013-14 Budget year as an increase to the Beginning Fund Balance for the General Fund.
			 
Board action is requested to approve the 2012-13 Unaudited Actual reports as presented with permission to proceed with any additional final year-end adjustments that may be necessary. 
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Unaudited Actual for 2012/2013 fiscal year report as presented with permission to proceed with any additional final year-end adjustments that may be necessary.

Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, Julie Kasberger, Director of General Services, and Randy Phelps, Director of Information Technology
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Summer Short-Term Staffing Outcome
		 
		 
On May 9, 2013 the Board adopted Resolution #2012/2013-31 to hire short-term non-certificated summer staffing.  Over the summer, 35 short term employees were hired to perform maintenance, repairs and grounds related work, computer recycling and updating fixed asset data, all of which had become backlogged due to significant budget cuts that reduced staffing levels.  This summer work initiative used Measure G, Measure E, Restricted Maintenance and General Funds totaling $182,421.72.
		 
The work that was completed enhanced the aesthetic, cleanliness, safety, security and operational functionality of the school campuses.  Performing the work over the summer months provided ease of access to school site facilities.  Staff in the areas of Facilities, Warehouse and Information Technology operations will present “what got done” as a result of this summer staffing initiative. 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$182,421.72
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure G, Measure E, Restricted Maintenance and General Fund

It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the attached report.

FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2013/2014-07 Ratify Itemized List of Surplus/Obsolete Equipment for Sale and/or Disposal per Education Code Sections 17545 and 17546 
			 
			 
Attached is a resolution and an itemized list of surplus equipment that is no longer needed for school purposes and will be sold and/or disposed of in accordance with Education Code Sections 17545 and 17546.  
			 
At the April 16, 2013 Board meeting the Board of Trustees approved authorization for the Superintendent and/or designee to dispose of surplus/obsolete furniture and equipment as needed and to report back to the Board on a semi-annual basis.  The term of this delegation is from April 17, 2013 through August 31, 2015.  
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2013/2014-07 an Itemized List of Surplus/Obsolete Equipment for Sale and/or Disposal pursuant to Education Code Sections 17545 and 17546.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  19.08
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of August 2013
		 
		 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of August 2013, in response to Board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the Board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.  
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Warrant Register as presented for the month of August 2013.

SUBJECT:
Approve Notice of Completion for the Andrew Hill, Piedmont Hills, James Lick, Oak Grove and Yerba Buena High Schools All Weather Track Re-surfacing Project, G-025-202, G-045-202, G-030-202, G-050-202, and G-060-202 (Hellas Construction, Inc.)
	 
Pursuant to the contract awarded by the Board of Trustees on June 27, 2013, Hellas Construction, Inc. has furnished all material and finished all labor for the completion of work related to the Andrew Hill, Piedmont Hills, James Lick, Oak Grove and Yerba Buena High Schools All Weather Track Re-surfacing Project, G-025-202, G-045-202, G-G-030-202, G-050-202, and G-060-202.  Due to unanticipated base conditions, Santa Teresa High School was removed from this project.
	 
With the approval of the Board of Trustees, the attached Notice of Completion will be filed with the Santa Clara County Recorder’s Office as required by law.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$5.00
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure G
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion for the Andrew Hill, Piedmont Hills, James Lick, Oak Grove and Yerba Buena High Schools All Weather Track Re-surfacing Project, G-025-202, G-045-202, G-030-202, G-050-202, and G-060-202 (Hellas Construction, Inc.).
